H0.text: A lipid that coats lactose molecules is lacking in the digestive systems of some individuals who are unable to digest the lactose found in cowâ€™s milk.

H1.text: An ability to produce lactose internally is what the digestive systems of individuals who are unable to digest lactose found in cow milk most likely lack.

H2.text: An enzyme that catalyzes lactose breakdown is most likely lacking in the digestive systems of individuals who cannot digest the lactose found in cow milk.

H3.text: A tolerance to lactose developed during childhood is what the digestive systems of individuals unable to digest the lactose found in cow milk most likely lack.

A6.text: Without lactase, lactose-intolerant people pass the lactose undigested to the colon where bacteria break it down, creating carbon dioxide which leads to bloating and flatulence.

A7.text: In most of the world's population, lactase transcription is down-regulated after weaning, resulting in diminished lactase expression in the small intestine, which causes the common symptoms of adult-type hypolactasia, or lactose intolerance.
